global_flags.description: This option shows the version number of the xauth executable.
This  option  indicates that xauth should attempt to break any authority file locks before proceeding.  Use this option only to clean up stale locks.
By default, xauth will use the file specified by the  XAUTHORITY  envi‐ ronment variable or .Xauthority in the user's home directory.

This option indicates that xauth should ignore any authority file locks.  Normally, xauth will refuse to read or edit  any  authority files that have been locked by other programs (usually xdm or another xauth).
This option indicates that xauth should not attempt to resolve any hostnames, but should simply always  print  the  host  address  as stored in the authority file.

This  option  indicates that xauth should operate quietly and not print unsolicited status messages.  This is the default if an xauth command is given on the command line or if the standard output is not directed to a terminal.

This option indicates that xauth should operate verbosely and print status messages indicating  the  results  of  various  operations (e.g.,  how many records have been read in or written out).  This is the default if xauth is reading commands from its standard input and its standard output is directed to a terminal.

subcommands.name: An
subcommands.description: authorization entry for the indicated display using the given protocol and key data is added to the authorization file.  The data is specified as an even-lengthed string of hexadecimal digits, each pair representing one octet.  The first digit of each pair  gives the  most  significant  4  bits of the octet, and the second digit of the pair gives the least significant 4 bits.  For example, a 32 character hexkey would represent a 128-bit value.  A protocol name consisting of just a single period is treated as  an  abbreviation for MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1.

subcommands.name: Authorization
subcommands.description: entries  for  each of the specified displays (or all if no displays are named) are printed on the standard output.  If the nlist command is used, entries will be shown in the numeric format used by the nextract command; otherwise, they are shown  in  a textual format.  Key data is always displayed in the hexadecimal format given in the description of the add command.

subcommands.name: HOME
subcommands.description: to get the user's home directory if XAUTHORITY isn't defined.

subcommands.name: If
subcommands.description: the  trusted  option  is used, clients that connect using this authorization will have full run of the display, as usual.  If un‐ trusted is used, clients that connect using this authorization will be considered untrusted and prevented from stealing or  tampering with data belonging to trusted clients.  See the SECURITY extension specification for full details on the restrictions imposed on un‐ trusted clients.  The default is untrusted.

subcommands.name: The
subcommands.description: timeout  option specifies how long in seconds this authorization will be valid.  If the authorization remains unused (no clients are connected with it) for longer than this time period, the server purges the authorization, and future attempts to connect using it will fail.  Note that the purging done by the server does not delete the authorization entry from the authorization  file.   The  de‐ fault timeout is 60 seconds.

subcommands.name: Users
subcommands.description: that have insecure networks should take care to use encrypted file transfer mechanisms to copy authorization entries between machines. Similarly, the MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1 protocol is not very useful in insecure environments.  Sites that are interested in additional security may need to use encrypted authorization mechanisms such as Kerberos.

subcommands.name: common
subcommands.description: -display  command line argument.  Display-specific information (such as the screen number) is unnecessary and will be ignored.  Same- machine connections (such as local-host sockets, shared memory, and the Internet Protocol  hostname  localhost)  are  referred  to  as  host‐ name/unix:displaynumber so that local entries for different machines may be stored in one authority file.

subcommands.name: exit
subcommands.description: If  any  modifications  have  been  made,  the  authority file is written out (if allowed), and the program exits.  An end of file is treated as an implicit exit command.

subcommands.name: extract
subcommands.description: extract entries into file

subcommands.name: generate
subcommands.description: use server to generate entry

subcommands.name: trusted
subcommands.description: clients using this entry are trusted

subcommands.name: untrusted
subcommands.description: clients using this entry are untrusted

subcommands.name: help
subcommands.description: print help

subcommands.name: info
subcommands.description: Information describing the authorization file, whether or not any changes have been made, and from where  xauth  commands  are  being read is printed on the standard output.

subcommands.name: list
subcommands.description: list entries

subcommands.name: merge
subcommands.description: merge entries from files

subcommands.name: nextract
subcommands.description: numerically extract entries

subcommands.name: nlist
subcommands.description: numerically list entries

subcommands.name: nmerge
subcommands.description: numerically merge entries

subcommands.name: quit
subcommands.description: The program exits, ignoring any modifications.  This may also be accomplished by pressing the interrupt character.

subcommands.name: remove
subcommands.description: remove entries

subcommands.name: version
subcommands.description: show version number of xauth ? list available commands
